title: Reflections on 6 years as a founder at Wren
content:
Friday marked my last day working on my first startup, Wren. I created the company in 2019 with my co-founders Mimi Tran Zambetti (now my fiancée), and Landon Brand. 

Over the years, we built a category-defining and category-leading marketplace, raised venture capital from prestigious investors like Y Combinator and Union Square Ventures, hired employees, let employees go, acquired competitors, got (partially) acquired ourselves, nearly ran out of money, eventually turned it around and reached profitability, and much more in-between. 

*Note: Landon and Mimi will continue running and growing Wren.*

I will do my best to chronicle my learnings, and perhaps more helpfully my failings and shortcomings, across six years building a startup straight out of college. Frankly, I am doing this more for myself than you (or anyone who happens to read this), so I apologize for anything lacking context. If you have questions, please find me online.

### The importance of great, not good, co-founders
My greatest leg-up in starting Wren was having two fantastic partners in crime, Mimi Tran Zambetti and Landon Brand. Seven years later, and Mimi is my fiancée, and Landon is officiating our wedding.

Over the course of many stressful years of work together, having co-founders you can efficiently and safely argue with is a massive advantage over less functional teams. Having an odd-number of founders is an added benefit, so there is never a stalemate when voting on a path forward.

Before we wrote our first line of code for Wren, the three of us signed a Founders Agreement to delineate responsibilities, roles, equity, terms of equity disbursement, and so-on. The document was confirmed and signed by a trusted and neutral third-party, Noam Wasserman.
